Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: My phone buzzes on the kitchen table, and I see a message from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Miss you!” I know she expects me to check in, to send a quick reply, maybe even call. It’s something she’s always asked of me, especially since I moved out. I start typing a response, but then my phone rings. It’s Mr. Goldstein from the synagogue. He sounds desperate—there’s a funeral prayer in half an hour, and they’re one person short for the minyan. He asks if I can come right away. I know how important it is in our tradition to help form a minyan, especially for a funeral prayer. But if I go, I’ll have to leave my phone behind, no texting or calling during services. My mom will worry if I don’t answer, and I can already imagine her voice, hurt and anxious. I stare at my phone, torn between being the attentive child my parents want and the committed Jew my community needs. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which role I’m supposed to honor first.
